conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the motion of a charged particle in a magnetic field, considering changes in velocity and magnetic field interaction due to the particle's trajectory and the geometry of the magnetic field setup.

The figure shows two regions of uniform magnetic fields on the left side of MN and the right side of PQ. The distance between MN and PQ is 2d. A thin insulating plate ab with a length of 4d is equidistant from MN and PQ. Point c is at the bottom left, and point f is horizontally aligned with the lower end b of the plate.

The particle is positively charged, injected from point c with velocity v0 at an angle of 45° to MN. The vertical component of velocity remains unchanged after collision with the insulating plate, while the horizontal component reverses direction but maintains its magnitude.
The magnetic field region is sufficiently long, the particle has mass m and charge q, and gravitational force is negligible.

The particle just leaves the magnetic field region on the left side of M for the first time at point f, which is at a distance of 2d from c and is on the same horizontal line as the lower end b of the plate.

The particle is injected at an angle of 45° to the magnetic field lines from point c with velocity v0. The vertical velocity component remains unchanged, and the horizontal velocity component reverses direction.
The particle follows a circular trajectory in the magnetic field due to its velocity being at an angle to the magnetic field lines.
The radius of the circular trajectory is determined to be r = 2d.
The magnetic force on the particle is given by F = qv_BB, where v_B is the velocity in the magnetic field.
Since the vertical velocity component remains unchanged and the horizontal component reverses direction, the magnetic force is perpendicular to the velocity.
The magnetic induction B is constant along the trajectory because the magnetic force is perpendicular to the velocity and the radius of the circular path is constant.
Since the radius r is constant at 2d, the magnetic induction B is also constant.
The magnitude of the magnetic induction B is determined to be B = 2d.
